resultsMetadata.author: Stanley A Renshon
resultsMetadata.description: …Debate on public issues--and where candidates stand on them-- have traditionally represented the focal point of presidential campaigns. In recent decades, however, rather than asking where candidates stand on the issues, the public increasingly wants to know who they are. The issue of character has thus come to dominate presidential elections. While there is increasing public awareness that the <mark>psychology</mark>, judgment, and leadership qualities of presidential candidates count, the basis on which…
resultsMetadata.title: The <mark>Psychological</mark> Assessment of Presidential Candidates

resultsMetadata.author: Pearl Oliner, Samuel P. Oliner, Lawrence Baron, Lawrence Blum
resultsMetadata.description: All but buried for most of the twentieth century, the concept of altruism has re-emerged in this last quarter as a focus of intense scholarly inquiry and general public interest. In the wake of increased consciousness of the human potential for destructiveness, both scholars and the general public are seeking interventions which will not only inhibit the process, but may in fact chart a new creative path toward a global community. Largely initiated by a group of pioneering social psychologists,…
resultsMetadata.subtitle: Philosophical, <mark>Psychological</mark>, and Historical Perspectives on Altruism

resultsMetadata.author: Bernard Jay Paris
resultsMetadata.description: …One of literature's greatest gifts is its portrayal of realistically drawn characters--human beings in whom we can recognize motivations and emotions. In Imagined Human Beings, Bernard J. Paris explores the inner conflicts of some of literature's most famous characters, using Karen Horney's psychoanalytic theories to understand the behavior of these characters as we would the behavior of real people. When realistically drawn characters are understood in <mark>psychological</mark> terms, they tend to escape…
resultsMetadata.subtitle: A <mark>Psychological</mark> Approach to Character and Conflict in Literature
resultsMetadata.title: Imagined Human Beings

resultsMetadata.author: Stanley A Renshon
resultsMetadata.description: …The Clinton presidency is pivotal, occurring at a particularly sensitive time in American and world history. The Cold War has ended; yet Americans face daunting social and economic problems and are increasingly divided about how to address them. In this perceptive <mark>psychological</mark> portrait of Clinton and his presidency, expert Stanley Renshon investigates whether Clinton has demonstrated the requisite qualities of judgment, vision, character, and skill to meet the challenges he faces, domestically…
resultsMetadata.subtitle: Bill Clinton and the Politics of Ambition
